results.title: Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film
results.brief_description: A two-part series composed of archival films, newsreels, stills and personal stories about Port Phillip Bay and its surrounds, its history, architect, beaches, piers and lifestyle from the late 1800s through to the 1990s.
results.title_for_label: Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film
results.description: A two-part series composed of archival films, newsreels, stills and personal stories about Port Phillip Bay and its surrounds, its history, architect, beaches, piers and lifestyle from the late 1800s through to the 1990s.
description_for_label: A two-part series composed of archival films, newsreels, stills and personal stories about Port Phillip Bay and its surrounds, its history, architect, beaches, piers and lifestyle from the late 1800s through to the 1990s.
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: The Top end
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film”.
Final part of a most comprehensive and fascinating two part history of Port Phillip Bay, dating back from the 1880s to present times and incorporating archival footage, both professional and amateur, to cover over a century of settlement in Port Phillip Bay. Part two focuses on the northern end of Port Phillip Bay, particularly the areas of Port Melbourne and St Kilda reflecting on their maritime histories and the inevitable changes each city has undergone over the last hundred years or so. From the days of royal visits arriving at St Kilda Pier to the huge passenger liners and warships docking at Port Melbourne’s Station Pier, through to remembering St Kilda when it was “the place in which to be seen” - Melbourne’s favourite playground for fun and leisure, swimming and sailing - to today’s commercial developments and resident protests to maintain the architectural heritage of both Port Melbourne and St Kilda. Broken up into six segments, this documentary also covers some of the Bay’s well-known sea baths, piers and beaches, famous (and some infamous) celebrities, politicians and sporting personalities, historical landmarks, buildings and events and provides some rare and nostalgic images of bygone times. Commentary by Paul Higgins.

results.title: The Southern portion
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Bayside reflections: Port Phillip Bay on film”.
Part one of a most comprehensive and fascinating two part history of Port Phillip Bay, dating back from the 1880’s to present times and incorporating archival footage, both professional and amateur, to cover over a century of settlement in Port Phillip Bay. In particular, focus is on the two main southern peninsulas of Mornington and Bellarine, including Queenscliff, Point Lonsdale, Geelong, Portsea, Sorrento, Mornington and Frankston. The program is divided into seven segments and covers many topics including paddle steamers, fishing, boating, maritime disasters and dramatic rescues, lighthouses, filmmaking, storytelling, environmental issues and the people and architecture of the time. Composed entirely of original film and uses newsreels, documentaries, tourism promotions, advertisements, home movies, dramatic features and short subjects. Commentary by Paul Higgins.

results.title: The Class
results.creator_credit: John Schlesinger, Huw Wheldon and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Monitor”.
A close-up of the work of a class in a drama school and of the methods used to train the aspiring actors and actresses. John Schlesinger’s command of the particular directing technique required is such that the film appears to have been made spontaneously during the forty minutes or so of the single class. In fact it needed a week’s shooting and a considerable amount of preparation in order to give this impression. The tutor (Harold Lang) uses the Mercy Speech from ‘The Merchant of Venice’ as a starting point in an improvisation by the students. Originally made for the BBC Television program ‘Monitor’, it is exciting to watch a production in the hands of a dedicated artist.

results.title: Sharpening and grinding
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic woodwork”.
This film shows an array of tools which it is essential to keep sharp. These include the chisel, paring chisel, mortise chisel, the gouge and other curved tools, the cutting edges of all of which need to be kept sharp on an oilstone. The correct way of doing this is shown in detail and the latter half of the film describes the regrinding of tools, ending with a reminder that rust is thae principal enemy of steel tools. This can be kept down by frequent sharpening and the use of vaseline on the tools when put away for any length of time.
